creator: frank.ulbrich@triaton.com
text:
APACHE 2.0.49 on MS Windows 2003 Server, running as service
-----------------------------------------------------------
Windows 2003 Eventlog Entry:
Event Type : Error
Event Source : Application Error
Event ID : 1000
Description: Faulting Application Apache.exe, version 2.0.49.0, faulting module 
ntdll.dll, version 5.2.3790.0, Fault address 0x0001d61b

creator: frank.ulbrich@triaton.com
text: I found this event recuring in my eventlog of my server.

We have the same configuration (Apache2.0.49 + Windows2003 Server) and get the 
similar errors. Up to 8 times per day appears the following messages:
- faulting application Apache.exe, version 2.0.49.0, faulting module unknown, 
version 0.0.0.0, fault address 0x00000000.
- faulting application Apache.exe, version 2.0.49.0, faulting module 
libapr.dll, version 0.0.0.0, fault address 0x0000768c.
- faulting application Apache.exe, version 2.0.49.0, faulting module 
mod_mem_cache.so, version 0.0.0.0, fault address 0x000010c2.

Regardless of this error-messages, the Apache continue to work (with app. 70 
req/sec) and he works fine.

Greetings
Ilona
creator: ifischer@is24.de
micke@screemer.nu
text:
I am getting this same error on 2.0.52 running on a windows xp SP2
I've disabled DEP, internal firewall and changed tcpip.sy to allow maximum connects.

I am getting this error every few minutes and then the server just freezes.

Faulting application Apache.exe, version 2.0.52.0, faulting module libhttpd.dll,
version 2.0.52.0, fault address 0x0001ba22. 

Faulting application Apache.exe, version 2.0.52.0, faulting module ntdll.dll,
version 5.1.2600.2180, fault address 0x00001230. 

When shutting down port 80 in the external firewall so that none can connect it
stays up and running forever.. But as soon as I let people connect again the
problem starts..

Anyone got any news??
With version 2.0.53 the error is still present on W2K3 machines..
creator: stke@gmx.li
jorton@redhat.com
text:
This is an "it crashed" bug report.  To further investigate a crash, either a
reliable reproduction case or a backtrace is needed.  (If that error log is a
backtrace disguised as XML can you translate it into something useful?)
